column1: Job vacancies, payroll employees, and job vacancy rate by provinces and territories, monthly, unadjusted for seasonality 1 2 3

column2: Data quality indicators are based on the coefficient of variation (CV), the non-response errors, the imputation errors, and subject matter expertise: A – Excellent; B - Very good; C - Good; D – Acceptable; E - Use with caution; F - Too unreliable to publish.
Estimates are preliminary before the associated quarterly data is released. The three monthly estimates in a quarter are revised as final when the quarterly estimates are released, or shortly after.
Data for the second and third quarters of 2020 are unavailable due to some Statistics Canada operations being temporarily suspended during the COVID-19 pandemic.

A job is vacant if it meets the following conditions: it is vacant on the reference date (first day of the month) or will become vacant during the month; there are tasks to be carried out during the month for the job in question; and the employer is actively seeking a worker outside the organization to fill the job. The jobs could be full-time, part-time, permanent, temporary, casual, or seasonal. Jobs reserved for subcontractors, external consultants, or other workers who are not considered employees, are excluded.
The employee" concept used in the Job Vacancy and Wage Survey (JVWS) is comprised of full-time employees
column7: and seasonal employees. It also includes working owners
column10: and other officers of incorporated businesses
column11: as well as employees who work off site (for example
column12: at home or on the road) but report to the location
column13: and those employees on paid leave. The "employee" concept used in the JVWS is meant to exclude owners or partners of unincorporated businesses and professional practices
column19: and military personnel. It also excludes employees on unpaid leave
column20: such as those on extended sick leave who are receiving insurance benefits."

column2: The employment estimates from the Job Vacancy and Wage Survey (JVWS) are calibrated to corresponding employment estimates from the <a href=https://www23.statcan.gc.ca/imdb/p2SV.pl?Function=getSurvey&SDDS=2612">Survey of Employment
column4: usually at the North American Industry Classification System sector (NAICS2) level by province. The reference period for JVWS is the first day of the month
column5: which corresponds to the previous month for SEPH. Therefore
column6: JVWS estimates for the current month are calibrated to SEPH estimates for the previous month. To improve timeliness of the preliminary JVWS estimates
column7: they are calibrated to preliminary SEPH employment estimates. The final JVWS estimates are calibrated to final SEPH employment estimates. Users wishing to analyse employment data are advised to use the most current Labour Force Survey and SEPH estimates."

column2: The job vacancy rate is the number of job vacancies expressed as a percentage of labour demand; that is, all occupied and vacant jobs.

column1: How to cite: Statistics Canada. Table 14-10-0371-01  Job vacancies, payroll employees, and job vacancy rate by provinces and territories, monthly, unadjusted for seasonality
